title: James Murray (boxer)
text:
James Murray (7 December 1969 – 15 October 1995) was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> professional <a href="bantamweight">bantamweight</a> <a href="Boxing">boxer</a>. He died as a result of injuries sustained in his last <a href="fight">fight</a>.
Career.
Murray was born in <a href="Lanark">Lanark</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. He won the <a href="British%20Boxing%20Board%20of%20Control">BBBofC</a> Scottish Area bantamweight title in November 1994, and defended it once.
On 13 October 1995, Murray was unknowingly a victim of a bleed in his brain; during the fight he fell to the floor of the ring and had a seizure. This match was against <a href="Drew%20Docherty">Drew Docherty</a> for the BBBofC British bantamweight title fight at the Hospitality Inn in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>. He died of brain injuries two days later, aged 25. Murray compiled a 15-win (5 by knockout), 2-loss, no draws record.
Prior to that, Bradley Stone died of a brain hemorrhage after he lost his fight for the BBBofC British <a href="super%20bantamweight">super bantamweight</a> title at the <a href="York%20Hall">York Hall</a> in <a href="London">London</a> in April 1994. <a href="Frank%20Warren%20%28promoter%29">Frank Warren</a> who promoted Murray's last fight established the Murray Stone Fund named after those two boxers to finance the <a href="Magnetic%20resonance%20imaging">MRI</a> scan for every British fighter.
A bronze statue of Murray was erected in <a href="Newmains">Newmains</a>, <a href="North%20Lanarkshire">North Lanarkshire</a>, Scotland in the following year.
